Description: Typical range for 1064 nm Nd:YAG lasers in stone/brick cleaning to remove contaminants without thermal damage; starting at 200W balances efficiency and safety. Max avoids cracking due to brick's low thermal conductivity (~0.8 W/mK). Source: Manufacturer specs from IPG Photonics (e.g., YLR series for restoration); academic review in 'Laser Cleaning of Stone Surfaces' (Optics & Lasers in Engineering, 2015).
Near-infrared wavelength for optimal brick absorption and minimal substrate damage
Beam spot diameter for effective cleaning resolution on brick surface texture
Optimal repetition rate for efficient cleaning coverage and thermal management
Nanosecond pulse duration for effective contaminant removal with controlled thermal penetration
Optimal scanning speed for uniform cleaning coverage and process efficiency
Recommended number of passes for complete contaminant removal from porous brick surface
Optimal beam overlap percentage for uniform cleaning without excessive thermal accumulation
